dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh my god, not this again.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh my god, not this again.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, but wait, hear me out! The EU, okay, they're actually gonna do it. January 2026, tariffs on countries that don't price carbon.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, but wait, hear me out! The E U, okay, they're actually gonna do it. January twenty twenty six, tariffs on countries that don't price carbon.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Beginning in January 2026, the EU will start imposing tariffs on imports from countries that do not price carbon at the blocs market rate, which could significantly affect carbon-intensive producers among its trading partners.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Tariffs. Yeah, because what the global economy needs right now is, like, more trade wars, right? Just more international discord, uh-huh.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Tariffs. Yeah, because what the global economy needs right now is, like, more trade wars, right? Just more international discord, uh-huh.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The EUs new carbon-pricing regime may seem like a potential source of international discord, adding to the already overcrowded agenda of daunting global challenges.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, but this is different! This isn't just talk. This is, like, forcing the issue. Remember back in '94, how hard it was to get anyone to agree to anything because of the economic costs?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, but this is different! This isn't just talk. This is, like, forcing the issue. Remember back in 'ninety four, how hard it was to get anyone to agree to anything because of the economic costs?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 1994, when the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change entered into effect, it was clear that getting countries to agree to and comply with limits on GHG emissions would be extremely difficult, owing to the substantial economic costs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, they called it the "free-rider problem," right? Empty pledges, always. What's changed?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, they called it the free-rider problem, right? Empty pledges, always. What's changed?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Given the free-rider problem, international proclamations of ambitious climate targets were widely expected to amount to nothing more than empty pledges.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: The CBAM! The Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism. It's designed to prevent "leakage," so industries can't just move to places with lax regulations. They'll face tariffs on things like, uh, aluminum, steel, cement.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The C B A M! The Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism. It's designed to prevent leakage, so industries can't just move to places with lax regulations. They'll face tariffs on things like, uh, aluminum, steel, cement.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Now, the CBAM designed to prevent leakage when regulated industries move production from countries with strict environmental regulations to those with more lenient ones... Under the CBAM, countries that do not tax GHGs will, in effect, face tariffs on their exports to the EU in six carbon-intensive pilot sectors: aluminum, iron and steel, cement, fertilizers, hydrogen, and electricity.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, like, a new tax. Another way for the EU to, I don't know, line its pockets. What about the WTO? They'll just challenge it, obviously.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, like, a new tax. Another way for the E U to, I don't know, line its pockets. What about the W T O? They'll just challenge it, obviously.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While some might argue that such trade penalties are incompatible with World Trade Organization rules and could be used to support protectionist policies, the EU claims that this will not happen with the CBAM.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But the point is, it incentivizes countries to set their own carbon prices! So they collect the revenue instead of the EU. The UK's doing it, Turkey's developing one, Australia and Canada are looking at it...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But the point is, it incentivizes countries to set their own carbon prices! So they collect the revenue instead of the E U. The U K's doing it, Turkey's developing one, Australia and Canada are looking at it...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This would enable participating governments to collect revenue that would otherwise be collected by European governments... In December, the United Kingdom, which has its own domestic emissions market, decided to follow its continental neighbors and adopt a similar border-adjustment mechanism. Turkey is also developing its own carbon border tax, while Australia and Canada are reportedly considering similar measures.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and China's apparently fast-tracking a competing one to penalize the EU right back. And the US? We'll just say our steel is cleaner, so it's discriminatory against us without a national price.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and China's apparently fast-tracking a competing one to penalize the E U right back. And the U S? We'll just say our steel is cleaner, so it's discriminatory against us without a national price.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While countries like China, India, and South Africa have challenged the CBAM, the EUs new regime may prompt them to develop their own carbon-pricing mechanisms to mitigate the impact on their exports and GDP.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, okay, but that's the whole point. It puts pressure on everyone, including the US, to, like, finally put a real price on carbon.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, okay, but that's the whole point. It puts pressure on everyone, including the U S, to, like, finally put a real price on carbon.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By taxing GHG emissions, the CBAM will effectively give EU trading partners that export carbon-intensive goods a powerful incentive to establish carbon-pricing mechanisms and CBAMs of their own. As more countries join, the economic pressure on holdouts to follow suit is expected to increase.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Or, you know, they'll just use it as an excuse for plain old protectionism. "Domestic industries," blah blah.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Or, you know, they'll just use it as an excuse for plain old protectionism. Domestic industries, blah blah.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To be sure, carbon border taxes may serve as mere excuses for protecting domestic industries from imports.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But if it works though! This could be, like, the most effective global path to achieving the Paris Agreement goals. Seriously, this could be our best chance to get everyone on board.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But if it works though! This could be, like, the most effective global path to achieving the Paris Agreement goals. Seriously, this could be our best chance to get everyone on board.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But a closer look suggests that the CBAM could represent the most effective global path toward achieving the Paris climate agreements ambitious emissions-reduction goals... This could be the best chance the world has to facilitate the necessary technological, production, and consumption changes needed to avert catastrophic climate change.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, I mean it! It forces the technological, production, and consumption changes needed to, you know, avoid catastrophic climate change. It's not just, um, hand-waving anymore.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, I mean it! It forces the technological, production, and consumption changes needed to, you know, avoid catastrophic climate change. It's not just, um, hand-waving anymore.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This could be the best chance the world has to facilitate the necessary technological, production, and consumption changes needed to avert catastrophic climate change.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Until the EU just, uh, quietly diverts all that new revenue into some vague "climate-defense fund" instead of sending it back, like critics are suggesting.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Until the E U just, uh, quietly diverts all that new revenue into some vague climate-defense fund instead of sending it back, like critics are suggesting.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, but still, the economic pressure it puts on holdouts... Imagine if everyone had to do this.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, but still, the economic pressure it puts on holdouts... Imagine if everyone had to do this.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As more countries join, the economic pressure on holdouts to follow suit is expected to increase.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But a headache that, like, actually solves the free-rider problem! For the first time, ever.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But a headache that, like, actually solves the free-rider problem! For the first time, ever.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Given the free-rider problem, international proclamations of ambitious climate targets were widely expected to amount to nothing more than empty pledges... By taxing GHG emissions, the CBAM will effectively give EU trading partners that export carbon-intensive goods a powerful incentive to establish carbon-pricing mechanisms and CBAMs of their own.
